awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: The Development Of Social Complexity In A Foraging Society
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project examines how coastal foragers organized their domestic practices, strategies for food collection, and the production of crafted goods in the context of a changing regional political landscape. Archaeological research provides a unique and valuable perspective on organizational variation in human societies because of its time depth and ability to access past social and ecological conditions. Hunter-gatherers throughout time have maintained extremely variable forms of political, economic, and social organization, but their means of acquiring and managing surplus and social authority may differ from agricultural societies. Some non-agricultural groups maintained institutional differences in wealth, rank, and authority; others utilized cooperative efforts, temporary leadership, or ritual practice to undertake feats like constructing impressive monumental works or establishing trade networks for specialized artisan products. This project focuses on a particular case of complex coastal hunter-gatherer development in order to contribute to the broader topic of organizational variation among foragers. In addition to extensive and ongoing educational and public outreach, this project will also contribute a detailed, contextualized record of plant and animal remains that may provide valuable data for future studies of coastal and estuary environments.

University of Michigan doctoral student Christina Sampson, supervised by Dr. Robin Beck, will investigate the community organization of fisher-hunter-gatherers living on Weeden Island on Florida's Gulf Coast in late prehistory. This project will provide unprecedented extensive and systematically-collected data from domestic deposits. The culture area was located between complex agricultural Mississippian groups to the north and complex hunter-gatherer Calusa polities to the south. This position would have afforded opportunities for trade, competition, and the exchange and development of new ideas. The project's research questions are focused on four topics: (1) the social scale of domestic practices, (2) the tempo of occupation, (3) the extent of local authority over subsistence practices, and (4) the extent of inter-regional interaction. This project will use materials from the investigator's recent excavations at the Weeden Island site to generate data including AMS radiocarbon dates, the types and distributions of animal and plant foods consumed on site, and the attributes and locations of artifacts related to trade and craft production.

por.por_cntn:
Funding from the NSF supported dissertation research by Christina Sampson to explore how daily domestic practices shape community organization and contribute to regional historical trajectories of change. The project is an archaeological case study of the pre-Columbian Safety Harbor occupation (ca. AD 1000-1500) of the Weeden Island site, located on the west central peninsular Gulf Coast of Florida.

Safety Harbor residents of Weeden Island occupied a coastal locale with access to estuarine resources including fish, shellfish, and the mammals, birds, and reptiles of the local upland terrestrial forests. They also lived in a region neighboring powerful and increasingly complex groups, the Calusa of South Florida and Mississippian societies of the greater Southeast. Archaeologists also recognize that Safety Harbor settlement systems were changing, potentially as a result of new ideologies and sociopolitical principles.

The project began with geophysical remote sensing survey to reveal the location and extent of buried deposits adjacent to the more visually prominent shoreline midden ridges at the site. Sampson led field crews in excavations at the locations of magnetic anomalies detected in that survey. Excavations uncovered domestic contexts including locations for the processing and preparation of food and the manufacture of objects ranging from subsistence items (stone tools) to shell ornaments. While minimal structural remains are preserved at this site due to the environment and the use of perishable materials, excavations produced evidence of residential activity including scattered postholes and likely occupational surfaces.

Researchers analyzed materials recovered from excavation to learn about strategies for food collection, craft production, and participation in inter- and intra-regional exchange. The stylistic and formal analysis of ceramic artifacts shows how different types of pottery became more or less common over the course of the occupation, which is useful for ongoing efforts to understand social change at a human scale. Analysis of lithic debitage, artifacts that result from the manufacture and maintenance of stone tools, reinforce the relative sedentism of Safety Harbor populations at the site and point to differences in the focus of tool production activities in different parts of the occupation. A contextual analysis of artifacts associated with shell ornament crafting suggest that these activities were spatially segregated at the site, and perhaps socially marked as well.

NSF funding supported zooarchaeological identification and analysis of vertebrate animal bone, macrobotanical identification of plant remains, and radiocarbon dating. A comparison of vertebrate and invertebrate zooarchaeological assemblages shows variability in the relative contributions of fishing and hunting to different deposits, representing variation over time and in the use of different areas of the site. In general, mollusk resources predominate but terrestrial and fish resources are more common in certain feature contexts. Furthermore, the analysis of fish bone remains point to the ubiquitous use of mass capture fishing techniques, likely including gill nets, though individual capture methods like spearing or the use of trolling hooks were also used. The analysis of plant remains shows some use of mast (acorn and hickory), a potentially storable resource. Radiocarbon dating shows that the site was occupied continuously through the pre-contact phases of Safety Harbor. This study also revealed the use of at least some portions of the site during the early post-contact era. Areas of intensive occupation identified in the geophysical survey appear to have been used in overlapping sequence, with later occupation focused at the northern extent of the survey area.

This study shows that while there were abundant opportunities for the local coordination of community labor in subsistence activities, the crafting of tradeable shell ornaments was a likely venue for social change in Safety Harbor residential and regional communities. At the local scale, coastal Safety Harbor communities focused on the production of shell beads, and this may also have been an area of experimentation with new divisions of labor, or the development of new ideological or ceremonial concepts. By transitioning from peripheral participants in Weeden Island era ceremonial culture to purveyors of raw and crafted shell goods, Safety Harbor people created a new role for themselves on the regional landscape, with implications for local historical trajectories.

This project provided opportunities for students and community members to participate in archaeological research. Undergraduate students in anthropology and related fields received training in field and lab research techniques, including excavation, artifact analysis, and the sorting and identification of zooarchaeological remains. Community members were also invited to participate in field research as a way of learning about the site's history, scientific practices, and opportunities for environmental and cultural preservation. The project also involved outreach to younger community members, including an on-site workshop with the South Florida Museum and a partnership with the Florida Public Archaeology Network to bring in children and other volunteers to sort and explore midden samples.
